If datasets are not open, then some negotiation may be required with the rights holder to see what can be done to ensure third party data can be used in a way compatible with the policies and processes set out in the conditions of the grant or those in country. This could include helping data holders to address any concerns they have related to data sharing or to set up a data sharing agreement.

title: What to do when things are unclear
body:
In some cases, the reuse permissions related to a dataset might be unclear and a rights holder not listed. Following investigation you might even be bounced between people and get nowhere.

In this situation, data may still be usable and this use covered by a fair use (or fair dealing) exception or other local law.

If this is not the case, then a risk based decision could be made over the collection, use and sharing of the data. This is done with the understanding that the rights holder could reemerge and it may be necessary to backtrack, negotiate continued use, or potentially face a legal challenge.

title: Considering reusability of data from third party sources
body:
This may involve:

  • Ensuring third party data is using standards compatible with your needs. This might include standards for how the data is collected, the units of collection as well as how the data is represented and exchanged
  • Checking coverage. Does the data actually relate to what you require, e.g. the geography?
  • The timeliness of the data:  Does it cover the right period, is it up to date?
  • The granularity of the data. Is it as precise and include enough detail to be used in the ways intended?

title: A decision making flowchart for using data from third party sources
displayTitle: A decision making flowchart for using data from third party sources

title: Understanding the stakeholders and roles within a data ecosystem
displayTitle: Understanding the stakeholders and roles within a data ecosystem
body: Can you match the following descriptions with the right stakeholders within the ecosystem in relation to reuse of data from third party sources?

_items.text: Reuser of data to help develop and scale solutions based upon insights for consumers, needs to ensure rights and permissions to use data within solutions.
Responsible for ensuring everyone in the grant ecosystem has the appropriate rights and permission to access, use and share data, to ensure success of the grant.
Collector and reuser of data. Collects and analyses raw data, needs to ensure that rights and permissions are obtained and provided that allow the storage, use and sharing of the data with others.
Data steward. In charge of managing a number of key national datasets, needs to provide permissions for others to use the data and protect the rights of those the data is about.

Responsible for delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments. This includes ensuring that investments deliver impact and are in line with objectives and policies, and supporting the grantee through capacity building and facilitating conversations with other stakeholders in the data ecosystem where necessary.
Responsible for national policies on data and information. These contribute to the enabling environment in-country and set expectations on access, use and sharing of data.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

There are many stakeholders in a data ecosystem, some will be directly involved in an investment while many important stakeholders will be external or even international. It is the responsibility of the lead organisation to understand the environment, engage stakeholders and work with program officers to ensure that the best possible outcomes are achieved and that data is FAIR and safeguarded.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

There are many stakeholders in a data ecosystem, some will be directly involved in an investment while many important stakeholders will be external or even international. It is the responsibility of the lead organisation to understand the environment, engage stakeholders and work with program officers to ensure that the best possible outcomes are achieved and that data is FAIR and safeguarded.

title: Mapping data ecosystems
body:
Key to ensuring data is FAIR and safeguarded are the people, policies and processes that support its use. Many of the people are likely to be third party stakeholders and understanding the roles they play can be complex. Creating a map of a data ecosystem can help us to identify the key people, the relationships between them and the different roles they play. 

Representing data ecosystems visually can be particularly useful when contexts are complex, not well understood or not yet fully developed.

title: Mapping data spectrums
body:
A data ecosystem map also can be used to describe how data is being shared across The Data Spectrum. A map can show how data is being used to deliver a service, or show where data is not being shared. Understanding where value is or may be created from shared data will inform conversations with third parties on rights and permissions to reuse data.

The FAIR data toolbox contains a link to guides to help understand personas in agricultural ecosystems to use in conjunction with this methodology for mapping data ecosystems. The related materials on assessing the enabling environment should also be referred to when ensuring appropriate political, social, legal and technological frameworks are in place in-country to support FAIR and safeguarded data within investments.

title: Introduction
body:
Digitally-enabled services rely on sustainable access to relevant data, provided in a way that enables integration, analysis and reuse. Such services often require data from multiple third parties to even function, such as geographic data, population and socioeconomic data or sample data from previous projects. 

However, reusing data from existing third party sources can be complex. Grant proposals that set out with good intentions to reuse existing data often encounter constraints which should be addressed as soon as possible.

This module looks at the different barriers and techniques to address each.

_graphic.attribution: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation [All rights reserved]

title: Topics
body:
This module introduces:

  • The value of reusing data from third party sources
  • Barriers in reusing data from third party sources
  • The importance of rights and permissions in data
  • A spectrum of data rights
  • Identifying open, shared and closed data
  • Obtaining rights to reuse third party data
  • Considering compatibility with existing country and funder policies
  • Considering reliability and interoperability of data from third party sources
  • A decision making flowchart for using data from third party sources
  • The roles of different stakeholders in the data ecosystem
  • How to map a data ecosystem

title: The value of reusing data from third party sources
The value of reusing data from third party sources
body: Why use data from third party sources?

_items.text: Saves time in collecting data that already exists
Allows you to build upon and take advantage of existing investment in data collection
Allows you to claim ownership and recognition for someone else's work

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Digitally-enabled services rely on sustainable access to relevant data, provided in a way that enables integration, analysis and reuse. More than this, building on top of existing data saves significant time in collecting data that already exists. Building good relationships with data holders also means that you can build upon and take advantage of existing activities and communities around the data to support your aims. Furthermore, if the data is well maintained and of good quality, less of your own time will be required to prepare data prior to reuse. Encouraging reuse can help to reduce costs and increase returns (ROI) from previous investment in data collection and platforms.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Digitally-enabled services rely on sustainable access to relevant data, provided in a way that enables integration, analysis and reuse. More than this, building on top of existing data saves significant time in collecting data that already exists. Building good relationships with data holders also means that you can build upon and take advantage of existing activities and communities around the data to support your aims. Furthermore, if the data is well maintained and of good quality, less of your own time will be required to prepare data prior to reuse. Encouraging reuse can help to reduce costs and increase returns (ROI) from previous investment in data collection and platforms.

title: Constraints in reusing data from third party sources

_graphic.attribution: Designed by macrovector / Freepik [CC-BY]

title: Constraints in reusing data from third party sources
body: The list below contains common constraints to reusing data from third party sources, which do you think is the most common?

_items.text: A lack of processes and policies to share data
Data is not maintained
Data in wrong format or structure
Data is incomplete

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Even if the data exists and is well maintained, often those who hold it will not have clear policies and processes in place to support the sharing and reuse of data. This is most commonly due to concerns about risks and impacts related to the sharing of data. Working with stakeholders who hold data from early on in proposal development is essential to ensure the appropriate mechanisms are put in place (or enforced) to support the access to and sharing of data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Even if the data exists and is well maintained, often those who hold it will not have clear policies and processes in place to support the sharing and reuse of data. This is most commonly due to concerns about risks and impacts related to the sharing of data. Working with stakeholders who hold data from early on in proposal development is essential to ensure the appropriate mechanisms are put in place (or enforced) to support the access to and sharing of data.

title: The importance of rights and permissions in data
The importance of rights and permissions in data
body: All data available on the web is open and free to use. True or false?

_items.text: True
False

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Just because something can be accessed over the internet does not mean that it is free to use. For example, it is easy to screenshot or download company logos but these cannot then simply be used freely by anyone – the owner must grant permission for use. Unless it is published under a licence that allows reuse.

The same is true for data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Just because something can be accessed over the internet does not mean that it is free to use. For example, it is easy to screenshot or download company logos but these cannot then simply be used freely by anyone – the owner must grant permission for use. Unless it is published under a licence that allows reuse.

The same is true for data.

title: Introduction
body:
Some of the biggest barriers to delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments can be concerns of data security and privacy along with a mis-trust in data or others use of data. Understanding risks and being able to evaluate the real and perceived impact is critical to overcoming these barriers, increasing confidence in wider sharing of data while minimising harmful impacts.

This module introduces:

  • How to identify risks
  • Linking risks to impact
  • Analysing likelihood and severity
  • The impacts of NOT sharing data
  • Categories of risks and impact
  • Identifying risks in data
  • Strategies to help minimise risks
  • Tools to help identify and manage risk

_graphic.attribution: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation [All rights reserved]

title: Summary
body:
Common challenges to delivering FAIR and safeguarded data within investments are concerns of data security and privacy along with a mis-trust in data or other use of data. Understanding risks and being able to evaluate the real and perceived impact is critical to overcoming these challenges, increasing confidence in wider sharing of data while minimising harmful impacts. 

There are many risks and impacts associated with data, such as low quality data leading to reputational damage. However when managed carefully the likelihood and severity of impact from these risks could in fact be very low. There are negative impacts that can result from not sharing data, so it is important to also carefully consider these when doing any form of risk assessment for data. 

Key strategies to minimise impact from risks include: 

  • Supporting people with data literacy
  • Developing, enforcing and adhering to policies and processes for both data sharing as well as data protection.
  • Implementing data management plans
  • Being open in communication with stakeholders
  • Regularly reviewing risks and acting accordingly

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: Identifying risks and concerns
body: Which of the following are risks or concerns associated with sharing data?

_items.text: Data being of bad quality
Data getting into the wrong hands (e.g. a competitor)
Personal or sensitive information in the data
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

There are many risks or concerns that arise only when data is shared, such as data getting into the wrong hands. Others apply regardless of if the data is shared with others, such as bad quality data and handling of personal information. However while some concerns stem from real risks, such as reputational damage or breaking the law, the perceived and likely impact from others may be inflated.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

There are many risks or concerns that arise only when data is shared, such as data getting into the wrong hands. Others apply regardless of if the data is shared with others, such as bad quality data and handling of personal information. However while some concerns stem from real risks, such as reputational damage or breaking the law, the perceived and likely impact from others may be inflated.

title: The terminology of risks
body:
Sometimes it’s hard to work out how we’re going to address and minimise risk. The most common reason for this is because we haven’t described the risk correctly. To decide how we’re going to minimise a risk, we first need to define some key elements. These are:

  • An action: the thing we want to do
  • A concern: something that might go wrong
  • A cause: the reason it might go wrong
  • An impact: the result if it goes wrong

All of these together make up the risk.

title: Risks: What can you control?
body: These four elements make up the risk. If I want to minimise risk, which of these elements is something you can control or affect?

_items.text: Action
Concern
Cause
Impact

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The impact is the only element of the risk that is NOT directly under  your control. Many risks start as concerns about something that hasn’t yet happened, these concerns need to be evaluated to identify if they are (1) Genuine, (2) Likely and (3) Severe. Following this, causes can be addressed and appropriate actions taken to minimise negative impact.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The impact is the only element of the risk that is NOT directly under  your control. Many risks start as concerns about something that hasn’t yet happened, these concerns need to be evaluated to identify if they are (1) Genuine, (2) Likely and (3) Severe. Following this, causes can be addressed and appropriate actions taken to minimise negative impact.

title: Identifying actions, concerns, causes and impacts

_items.text: Data getting to the wrong hands
Data not being validated when entered into a system
Someone using the data to harm another individual
Data is published online

title: Identifying actions, concerns, causes and impacts
Concern: Data being of bad quality
body: Concern: Data being of bad quality

_items.text: Damage to organisation’s reputation
Organisation being fined for breaking the law
Discrimination against people or groups
Loss of competitive advantage

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The most likely impact resulting from bad quality data is damage to an organisation's reputation. The severity of this will depend on just how bad the data quality is; all data has errors so some should always be expected. Not checking the quality of the data before using it could also lead to discrimination against people or groups.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The most likely impact resulting from bad quality data is damage to an organisation's reputation. The severity of this will depend on just how bad the data quality is; all data has errors so some should always be expected. Not checking the quality of the data before using it could also lead to discrimination against people or groups.

title: Concern: Data getting into the wrong hands
body: Concern: Data getting into the wrong hands

_items.text: Damage to organisations reputation
Organisation being fined for breaking the law
Discrimination against people or groups
Loss of competitive advantage

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The potential impacts from data getting into the wrong hands can be very widespread depending on the type of the data and any external factors that control such data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The potential impacts from data getting into the wrong hands can be very widespread depending on the type of the data and any external factors that control such data.

title: Concern: Personal or sensitive information in the data
body: Concern: Personal or sensitive information in the data

_items.text: Damage to organisation’s reputation
Organisation being fined for breaking the law
Discrimination against people or groups
Loss of competitive advantage

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Personal and sensitive information should be handled with care. Many data protection regulations now stipulate that organisations can only collect what is necessary, not whatever they like. Even without a data breach, legal and/or reputational damage could result if it is discovered organisations are hoarding personal information unnecessarily. A breach in data protection regulations can also lead to discrimination against people or groups.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Personal and sensitive information should be handled with care. Many data protection regulations now stipulate that organisations can only collect what is necessary, not whatever they like. Even without a data breach, legal and/or reputational damage could result if it is discovered organisations are hoarding personal information unnecessarily. A breach in data protection regulations can also lead to discrimination against people or groups.

title: Analysing likelihood and severity
body:
To assess if something is a real risk it is important to evaluate the likelihood and the severity of the impact. A common method of doing this is to complete a risk matrix and assign a risk score.

It is important to remember that while the impact of different risks could be the same, e.g. “Damage to organisations reputation”, the likelihood and severity scores could be significantly different depending on the risk and wider context of the risk within the organisation.

It is also likely to vary widely depending on the organisation's attitude towards the risk. For example, is sharing poor quality data, which is likely most of the time, actually high in severity? especially if you tell people the data is likely to contain errors due to the way it was collected.

title: The risks of NOT sharing data
The risks of NOT sharing data
body:
Many risk assessments associated with data sharing only consider the risks and impacts associated with sharing data, this is not balanced with the risks and impacts of NOT sharing data. 

Which of the following are impacts that can result from not sharing data?

_items.text: Discrimination against people or groups
Damage to organisations reputation
Organisation being fined for breaking the law
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The risks are all the same. Sometimes it is of greater risk to be closed, than open. When building a risk assessment you should always consider the impact of both sharing and not sharing data and take a balanced approach.

For example, negative headlines attempting to damage reputations of organisations will exist regardless of if data is made available widely. The advantage of data associated with negative headlines being open is that people can fact check the headline from the raw data; if the data is not available, there is no way to refute the headline, thus the reputational damage severity resulting from not sharing data could in fact be higher.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The risks are all the same. Sometimes it is of greater risk to be closed, than open. When building a risk assessment you should always consider the impact of both sharing and not sharing data and take a balanced approach.

For example, negative headlines attempting to damage reputations of organisations will exist regardless of if data is made available widely. The advantage of data associated with negative headlines being open is that people can fact check the headline from the raw data; if the data is not available, there is no way to refute the headline, thus the reputational damage severity resulting from not sharing data could in fact be higher.

title: Legal and ethical risks to people
Legal and ethical risks to people
body:
Legal risks: 

It may be discovered that data you are sharing contains personal information that does not have a lawful basis for being stored or shared.

Ethical risks:

While the collection, use or sharing of data may be lawful, it could still result in unethical outcomes, such as discrimitation or exclusion. For example, an automated data model might make decisions about whether someone is eligible for benefits or subsidies, or what products they can be offered.
instruction: Click the heading below to view strategies to reduce these risks.

_items.title: Reducing legal risks
_items.body: Regardless of if data is shared or not, you should always check you have a lawful basis for handling personal data. Is the personal information necessary to deliver the service or could techniques like suppression or anonymisation be used to remove the personal information from the data?

_items.title: Reducing ethical risks
_items.body: Discrimination most often is the result of using a limited amount of biased data. Wider data sharing can help boost the variety of data available and potentially address biases in the data. Putting in place ethical codes of practice, publishing impact assessments, communicating openly and regularly reviewing practices are key to help minimise harmful impacts of data.

title: Commercial risks
body: Commercial risks come in many forms, especially as sharing data may lead to challenges to business models. Sometimes however, these risks may be better seen as opportunities.
instruction: Click the headings below to find out more about the different types of commercial risk

_items.title: Affiliation risks
_items.body:
This is where a company you do not wish to be associated with making use of your data or services. 

Solution: To address this you should make clear in your licensing that use of your data does not act as an endorsement and that your trademarks and logos are not to be used.

_items.title: Revenue risks
_items.body: Being more open may mean changes to an organisation's revenue model. This change is not without opportunity however. Additional revenue might be available through offering support and consultancy services to those who use it commercially. Conversely, being more open with data may be required to meet funder policy requirements; revenue from this route may not be available without being open with data.

_items.title: Imitation risks
_items.body: Imitation risks are linked to other organisations offering similar products and services to your own, potentially reusing your own shared data. Again this may have an impact on revenue. With work that is specifically designed to benefit society and the environment, such as agricultural services, imitation may be a sign of success and lead to sustainability and widespread adoption of good practices. This might allow organisations operating in this space more opportunity for innovation and seeking of the next breakthrough. Alternatively, applying for patents on products and services, as opposed to restricting access to data, might be a route to protect revenue while still widening opportunities for data sharing and reuse.

_items.title: Copycat risks
_items.body:
One step beyond imitation is copycat risks, where there is a deliberate and targeted attempt to masquerade as another organisation, e.g. to sell fake goods and services. 

Solution: Again, while reuse of shared data might play a factor, you should make it clear in your licensing that use of your data does not act as an endorsement and that your trademarks and logos are not to be used.

title: Reputation risks
body:
Data quality risks: 

Data that is inaccurate, contains personal information, not updated regularly or too suppressed may all affect your reputation. This can undermine the strategic benefits of publishing open data and may contradict legal or other policy requirements. Potential users may not see you as a credible publisher and in turn avoid using your data and/or services.
instruction: Click the heading below to view strategies to reduce this risk.

_items.title: Reducing data quality risks
_items.body: Develop a robust data management plan that includes being as open as possible with data. The plan should detail the quality control mechanisms, time schedules and processes that ensure data is as open and accessible as possible. Don’t guarantee quality, rather develop channels where consumers can communicate with you and endeavour to respond quickly.

title: Wider economic, societal and environmental risks
displayTitle: Wider economic, societal and environmental risks
body:
Releasing data, or holding onto data, can result in wider harmful impacts on society, the economy or the environment. 

For example publishing data that highlights the location of key food production and storage areas for internal use and export could make those locations a target in times of conflict.

Conversely,not sharing data on crop disease can result in the disease becoming widespread before anyone is even aware it exists, meaning it is too late to suppress and stop. However, releasing the data may result in commercial harm (or not as we have seen). The choice of which risk is greater in magnitude and importance is often complex. 

Putting in place, or upholding existing and widely accepted ethical codes of practice, communicating openly and regularly reviewing practices are key to help minimise harmful impacts of data.

title: Identifying risks in data
body:
Looking directly at the data, try to establish:

  • Could the data directly, or indirectly, identify individuals?
  • Does the data contain sensitive information?
  • Does the data contain any confidential information?
  • Does the data contain free text fields? Have these been analysed in respect to the above?

title: Identifying risks in data
body:
Think about impacts (e.g. impacts of national security, organisations, people and society)?:

  • What are you trying to achieve by collecting, sharing or using data?
  • What positive impacts might there be?
  • What negative impacts might there be

title: Strategies to help minimise risks
body: There are many actions that can be taken to help minimise risks, including:

_items.title: 1. Increasing data literacy
_items.body:
Many challenges in data collection, access, use and sharing are related to a lack of core data literacy. 

Working with stakeholders to increase data literacy in key areas such as data collection, handling personal and sensitive data and rights and permissions is critical to the success of any project involving data.

_items.title: 2. Implementing a data management plan
_items.body:
A good data management plan supports the safeguarding of data. A good plan sets out the processes that support the policies including:

  • how to store and share data 

  • data lifecycle and retention/deletion requirements 

  • when and how risks, legal requirements and ethical practices are reviewed

  • how data users and external stakeholders are supported

See Developing a data management plan: a checklist

_items.title: 3. Using a variety of data licenses and data sharing agreements
_items.body:
Not all data has to be licensed the same way. Different versions of the same dataset can exist at different places on the data spectrum.

For example, if it is necessary to share a dataset containing personal data, then a data sharing agreement could be used, while an anonymised version of the same dataset could be made openly available in parallel.

_items.title: 4. Documenting and communicating openly
_items.body:
Many risks can be addressed through open communication and good documentation. From establishing rights to access, use and share a dataset owned by a third party, addressing data quality issues to concerns over how others will use data. Documenting and publishing policies and processes, impact assessments, known data quality issues and limitations of the data are all things that can lower risk. 

Being open and welcoming input and feedback are essential to help build a healthy ecosystem around the data.

title: Tools to help identify and manage risk
displayTitle: Tools to help identify and manage risk
body: The FAIR data toolbox contains key resources that can help everyone carefully consider risk and reduce harmful impacts from data while ensure utility is maximised. Discover more about each below:

_items.title: Cheat sheet: Minimising harmful impacts from data
_items.body: Summarises the key points from this learning.

_items.title: Case study: Sharing data while maintaining a competitive advantage
_items.body: Looks at how one organisation has tackled the commercial risks associated with wider data sharing.

_items.title: Sharing agricultural data: risk assessment
_items.body:
This step by step guide will help program officers and grantees wanting to publish data. Specifically it will help:

  • recognise where data is suitable for sharing as openly and widely as possible
  • comply with data protection and data rights legislation 
  • minimise risk by identifying relevant mitigating actions (e.g. anonymisation)

_items.title: Tech Transformed Consequence Scanning toolkit
_items.body:
Many leaders of the biggest tech companies of our time have admitted that they simply did not think of the consequences of what they were creating.

Consequence scanning is a practice that allows organisations to surface issues that might not get raised otherwise and establish an open dialogue about those. 

Discover the toolkit here

_items.title: ODI Data Ethics Canvas
_items.body:
The ODI Data Ethics Canvas helps identify and manage ethical issues related to the FAIR and safeguarded collection, access, use and sharing of data.

Find out more about the canvas and download your own copy

_items.title: Developing a data management plan: a checklist
_items.body:
This document is intended to act as a checklist to support the creation of a data management plan for a research project. 

This checklist helps to:

  • ensure that data is not lost or corrupted
  • ensure the security of sensitive data
  • make data FAIR – Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable – so that value may be extracted from it by others, or in collaboration with them
  • ensure that data is made open, for anyone to access, use and share, where possible

Download a copy of the checklist

title: Publishing soil sample data
body:
What do you think the likelihood and severity is related to the following situation?

Action: Releasing location of a soil sample and the PH level in the soil (2 columns only)


Concern: Individual farms and farmers could be identified from the data


Perceived impact: Farmers might be targeted or discriminated against

_items.text: Likelihood
Impact

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

A simple soil sample resulting in discrimination is highly unlikely and a lot of additional data would be needed to identify the farmer; location and pH on their own are unlikely to enable re-identification of a farmer.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

A simple soil sample resulting in discrimination is highly unlikely and a lot of additional data would be needed to identify the farmer; location and pH on their own are unlikely to enable re-identification of a farmer.

title: Publishing crop infection data
body:
What do you think the likelihood and severity is related to the following situation?

Action: sharing data on pests or crop infections 


Concern: loss of revenue


Perceived impact: farmers with pest or crop infection experience damage to reputation and loss of trust in the product

_items.text: Likelihood
Impact

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

It has in fact been found that the opposite is true; sharing data resulted in farmers losing 20% fewer crops than normal, meaning higher revenue is maintained.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

It has in fact been found that the opposite is true; sharing data resulted in farmers losing 20% fewer crops than normal, meaning higher revenue is maintained.

title: Analysing likelihood and severity: Crime data
body:
What do you think the likelihood and severity is related to the following situation?

Action: Releasing crime data with detail at street level


Concern: A significant reduction in house prices in high crime areas


Perceived impact: People in high crime areas being unable to sell or rent out their houses

_items.text: Likelihood
Impact

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Many countries have published highly detailed crime data. Although many had concerns, there has been no significant impact as a result of the data being published. People simply didn’t know what high crime was and it is more about experiences than statistics.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Many countries have published highly detailed crime data. Although many had concerns, there has been no significant impact as a result of the data being published. People simply didn’t know what high crime was and it is more about experiences than statistics.

title: Reputation risks
body:
Mis-use risks:

A mis-trust in data or others’ use of data; drawing ‘incorrect’ conclusions that might be attributed to the publisher is a common barrier to openly publishing data. There is a perception that this will lead to reputational and potentially commercial damage.
instruction: Click the heading below to view strategies to reduce this risk.

_items.title: Reducing mis-use risks
_items.body: A mis-trust in others use of data can often lead to data not being shared. However, it is also important to ask how you battle misrepresentation or misuse? Any organisation could publish analysis that you know to be false, regardless of if the data is available or not, however people cannot refute the claims of others unless the data is available for them to analyse themselves. Sharing data as openly as possible can in fact fight misuse and misrepresentation rather than lead to more of it!

title: Introduction
body:
Value can be created from data when it is collected, accessed, used and shared. Maximising the value created from data can only be achieved when all of these aspects are considered. However this cycle is often broken as data is not shared and thus the same data cannot be collected and re-used by others. 

This module introduces the key role of data sharing agreements and data licenses as ways to safely share data and maximise its reuse.

_graphic.attribution: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation [All rights reserved]

title: Outcomes
body:
This module introduces:

  • The benefits of data sharing to the data publisher
  • Why data sharing agreements and licenses are important
  • The difference between data licenses and data sharing agreements
  • The role of data sharing agreements and data licenses with respect to FAIR and safeguarded data
  • Choosing between using a data sharing agreement and an data license
  • How to build a data sharing agreement
  • How to build an open license for data
  • Using existing open licenses for data
  • Choosing a license for data sharing

title: The benefits of data sharing to the data publisher
body: Which of the following are benefits of sharing data with others?

_items.text: Increased reputation and collaboration opportunities
Increased trust through transparency
Potential for data to be enriched and improved by others
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

There are many benefits of sharing data with others including: 

  • Increased reputation and collaboration opportunities
  • Increased trust through transparency
  • Potential for data to be enriched and improved by others
  • Potential economic growth and impact resulting from your data underpinning a commercial product.
  • Potential environmental & societal benefit resulting from your data underpinning information and support services.
  • An enlarged ecosystem gives potential new skills, knowledge and uses of your data you didn’t know were possible.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

There are many benefits of sharing data with others including: 

  • Increased reputation and collaboration opportunities
  • Increased trust through transparency
  • Potential for data to be enriched and improved by others
  • Potential economic growth and impact resulting from your data underpinning a commercial product.
  • Potential environmental & societal benefit resulting from your data underpinning information and support services.
  • An enlarged ecosystem gives potential new skills, knowledge and uses of your data you didn’t know were possible.

title: The benefits of data sharing to the data publisher
Why data sharing agreements and licenses are important?
body: Why are data sharing agreements and licenses important?

_items.text: Give users explicit and legal permissions to users of data
Put in place clauses that protect and distance the data publisher from any potential risks
Provide a highly lucrative way of making money from data

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Data sharing agreements and data licenses provide permission for users (e.g. academics, businesses, governments and individuals) to innovate with data. Both provide users with certainty that the data can be used and shared for a wide range of purposes. 

Without a license or data sharing agreement, both users and publishers may find themselves in a legal grey area.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Data sharing agreements and data licenses provide permission for users (e.g. academics, businesses, governments and individuals) to innovate with data. Both provide users with certainty that the data can be used and shared for a wide range of purposes. 

Without a license or data sharing agreement, both users and publishers may find themselves in a legal grey area.

title: The benefits of data sharing to the data publisher
The difference between data licenses and data sharing agreements
body:
Rights and permissions to access, use and share data are governed by a set of rules, policies, processes, legislation and community norms. 

To the end user however, rights and permissions most commonly exist in the forms of data licenses and data sharing agreements.

Both play key roles in ensuring data is FAIR and safeguarded.

title: Characteristics of data sharing agreements
body:
Data sharing agreements are usually contracts that will have been signed between two or more organisations sharing data. They set out the purpose and legal basis for sharing data as well as setting out how, when, where and for how long data will be shared.  

Data sharing agreements are most useful when organisations, of any kind, are sharing with detailed, binding rules about what each side may do and must do. This is useful in high-risk situations where the data is sensitive or personal, and is essential if one organisation is performing a task or contract for another and is being granted access to the data for that purpose. It helps everyone involved to be clear on their obligations and specifies roles and responsibilities.

Responsibilities could also include the requirement for organisations to make a version of the dataset available openly for others to use, setting requirements to remove or suppress sensitive and personal data before doing so. 

This checklist will help when designing data sharing agreements.

title: Characteristics of data licenses
body:
It differs from data sharing agreements in the following ways:

  • Permission is granted in advance, rather than when somebody asks for access.
  • Permission is not time-limited - there is no start and end date.
  • Rather than naming specific people or organisations, it applies to everyone (as long as they abide by the license terms)
  • A user does not typically sign an open data license
  • It usually contains at most three sets of conditions.
  • What must be done by the user
  • What can be done by the user
  • What cannot be done by the user

title: The role of data licenses and data sharing agreements with respect to FAIR and safeguarded data
body:
Data licenses play a key role in making data FAIR. Granting up front permissions for use means that that properly licensed data is Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable by anyone. Data licenses do not necessarily increase the findability of data, however the ability for others to redistribute data means that it can become more easily discoverable by others in different domains. 

Data sharing agreements are necessary when data needs to be shared but is more sensitive in nature and may need to be safeguarded, such as personal data.

It is important to balance the needs of data to be FAIR and Safeguarded when choosing a data sharing agreement or a data license. The additional learning module and materials on ‘managing risks’ is a good starting point when considering this.

title: The role of data licenses and data sharing agreements with respect to FAIR and safeguarded data
Choosing between using a data sharing agreement and a data license
body: Can you distinguish which is more appropriate in the following scenarios?

title: Choosing between using a data sharing agreement and a data license
Choosing between using a data sharing agreement and a data license

_items.text: I’m granting access but I want this to end after 12 months?
I’m hoping to support local developers to make apps?
I’m granting access so the user can do some work for me?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

If you are granting access to data under specific conditions, such as for a limited amount of time or for a very specific purpose then a data sharing agreement should be considered. 

Encouraging an ecosystem to emerge around your data, supporting developers and local communities with easily available data is best done with an open data license.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

If you are granting access to data under specific conditions, such as for a limited amount of time or for a very specific purpose then a data sharing agreement should be considered. 

Encouraging an ecosystem to emerge around your data, supporting developers and local communities with easily available data is best done with an open data license.

title: Choosing between using a data sharing agreement and a data license
Choosing between using a data sharing agreement and a data license

_items.text: This is sensitive/personal data that can’t be anonymised?
This data isn’t sensitive in any way and I don’t mind how people use it but I don't think they should make money from it?
I need to make sure I get the credit for collecting/sharing the data?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

When sharing personal or sensitive data this is usually done under a formally signed contract such as a data sharing agreement. As well as setting out the legal terms relating to the data sharing the agreement will set our roles and responsibilities that both parties agree to. 

A data license is more suited for generic terms that can cover the non-commercial restriction on data usage and the requirement for any user to give credit to the rights holder.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

When sharing personal or sensitive data this is usually done under a formally signed contract such as a data sharing agreement. As well as setting out the legal terms relating to the data sharing the agreement will set our roles and responsibilities that both parties agree to. 

A data license is more suited for generic terms that can cover the non-commercial restriction on data usage and the requirement for any user to give credit to the rights holder.

title: Choosing between using a data sharing agreement and a data license
Building a data sharing agreement
body:
A data sharing agreement sets out the purpose and legal basis for sharing data as well as setting out how, when, where and for how long data will be shared. 

Each agreement will likely be bespoke and focussed on a particular application or domain or purpose. 

Unlike a data license, a data sharing agreement will often go into much more detail on the scope and detail the characteristics of the data and how it should be used to fulfil a specific purpose. 

Often data sharing agreements are set up due to the need to share personal data between a data controller and a data processor. Here the lawful basis for sharing data is dictated by data protection regulations and will be detailed in the data sharing agreement. 

Finally, data sharing agreements are contracts so will require legal signatures from both parties.

title: Data sharing agreements in practice
body:
The Cereal Systems Initiative for South Asia has established a data sharing agreement pertaining to a particular dataset; the Landscape Diagnostic Survey data. This agreement has been put in place in order to facilitate the sharing of raw data between partners. As the raw data contains personal information, the agreement outlines the responsibilities of each party to protect the data and requires permission to be sought prior to the onward sharing of raw data. 

Additionally, by signing the agreement, all parties agree that curated and anonymised data will be made publicly available, under an open licence, within twelve months.

title: Building a data license
body:
A data license grants up-front permission to use and reuse data, so long as the user complies with a specified set of terms. Many organisations and governments around the world are adopting open data licenses for sharing data. 

See if you can sort the following conditions into the three boxes in order to build an open data license.
instruction: Drag your answers into each box and then click 'submit'

_items.text: A user can (with this data):
A use must (if they do anything with the data)
A user cannot
accepted: Seek damages for low quality data

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data licenses provide users with certainty that the data can be accessed, used, modified and shared for a wide range of purposes.

For a license to be an open one, it must give users explicit permission to use the data for both commercial and non-commercial purposes.

Publishers can require that users attribute the data provider or even share modifications to the data for others to benefit from. 

A data user cannot claim ownership, endorsement or any damages from the data publisher that result from their use or analysis of the data, regardless of the quality of the data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Open data licenses provide users with certainty that the data can be accessed, used, modified and shared for a wide range of purposes.

For a license to be an open one, it must give users explicit permission to use the data for both commercial and non-commercial purposes.

Publishers can require that users attribute the data provider or even share modifications to the data for others to benefit from. 

A data user cannot claim ownership, endorsement or any damages from the data publisher that result from their use or analysis of the data, regardless of the quality of the data.

title: Common licenses for data sharing
body:
The simpler the license, the better.

There are lots of different licenses. To maximise reuse, try to adopt a license standard that is already widely used - using an existing license can save you time and money and can help reusers understand what they can and cannot do via permissions written in standard wording that is widely used, therefore maximising the utility of data and potential value that can be unlocked

The FAIR data toolbox contains a guide on how to choose a license for data

There are also other licenses available, explore the common ones below:

title: Open government licenses
body:
Some publishers choose to adopt in-country government licenses. This has the advantage of being created and backed by local regulations. 

In the majority of cases these are similar, to the point of being completely compatible with, creative commons licenses. The only difference in some cases is the name, logo and jurisdiction of laws that govern the license. 

Some good examples of clear open government data licenses include:

  • The UK Open Government license
  • The Government Open Data License for India

title: Creative commons marks and licenses
body:
Creative Commons marks and licenses are widely used for open content. Version 4.0 explicitly considers data licensing. You can choose a license (or mark) that works for you at the Creative Commons website. 

There are three Creative Commons marks and licenses that are open:

_items.title: Public domain: (CC0)
_items.body: The public domain mark can be used by a copyright holder to waive all your rights over a piece of data, including copyright. This is particularly useful in the sharing of data and databases, since it otherwise may be unclear whether highly factual data and databases are restricted by copyright or other rights.

_items.title: Attribution: (CC-BY v4.0)
_items.body: The Creative Commons attribution license gives users rights to access, use and share (even commercially) your content. The only restriction is that the user must give credit to the data publisher (rights holder).

_items.title: Attribution & share-alike: (CC-BY-SA v4.0)
_items.body: The Creative Commons attribution & share-alike license is the same as the attribution license with the added restriction that the data user must share back any changes and modifications made to the data.

title: Choosing a license for data sharing

_items.text: I’m hoping to support local developers to make apps.
Others can benefit from my data but I would like the data to remain as open as possible.
This data isn’t sensitive in any way and I don’t mind how people use it but I don't think they should make money from it.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

For data to be open and support the development of apps you should choose a CC-BY or CC-BY-SA license. Choosing a non-commercial license such as CC-BY-NC limits what can be done with the data and its ability to be enriched with other data. If you want to benefit from commercial use of data, then a CC-BY-SA license may actually be a more appropriate choice as this will require the company to share back any modifications or changes they have made to the data. Many governments avoid this license however as it can put many off from using the data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

For data to be open and support the development of apps you should choose a CC-BY or CC-BY-SA license. Choosing a non-commercial license such as CC-BY-NC limits what can be done with the data and its ability to be enriched with other data. If you want to benefit from commercial use of data, then a CC-BY-SA license may actually be a more appropriate choice as this will require the company to share back any modifications or changes they have made to the data. Many governments avoid this license however as it can put many off from using the data.

title: Choosing a license for data sharing
Tools and guides to support data sharing
displayTitle: Tools and guides to support data sharing
body:
After completing this eLearning we recommend utilizing the following;

  • Cheat sheet: Data sharing to maximise utility

  • Guide: Deciding how to share data

  • Guide: How to choose a license for data

  • Checklist: Designing data sharing agreements

  • Guide: Data principles & policy for consortia

  • Explainer: Agriculture Data Spectrum

title: Summary
body:
Rights and permissions to access, use and share data are governed by a set of rules, policies, processes, legislation and community norms. 

To the end user however, rights and permissions most commonly exist in the forms of data licenses and data sharing agreements.

Data sharing agreements and licenses provide permission for users (e.g. academics, businesses, governments and individuals) to innovate with data. Without them such rights are unclear and innovation suffers as a result.

Unless a data sharing agreement is required, best practice for sustainability is to license data. To maximise reuse, try to adopt a license standard that is already widely used - using an existing license can save you time and money and can help users quickly understand what they can and cannot do with data.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: The difference between data licenses and data sharing agreements
Data licenses in practice
body:
There are many examples of data licenses in practice, with some of the worlds biggest websites such as wikipedia, flickr and scribd. In the agricultural sector the Innovative Solutions for Decision Agriculture Soil platform has launched soil information maps at a resolution of 30 meters, encompassing 24 billion unique locations across Africa. All data is easily accessible through an easy to use and well documented API and all available under a Creative Commons Attribution (CC-BY v4.0) licence. 

Explore the iSDAsoil platform for yourself

title: Ensuring sustainable access to data
body: Sustainable access to data is critical to ensure that data remains FAIR and safeguarded over the long term. It is one thing to make data Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable (FAIR), but building in sustainable access to data helps to maximise the utility of data as a wider group of people can use the data over time to make better decisions and reduce risk.

_graphic.attribution: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation [All rights reserved]

title: Introduction
body:
This module introduces:

  • The need for sustainable access to data
  • When to plan for sustainable access to data
  • The aspects that help ensure sustainable access to data
  • Exemplars in sustainable access to data
  • How to choose the right solution to ensure sustainable access to data
  • The role of a data management plan in ensuring sustainable access to data
  • Tool and guides to help ensure sustainable access to data

title: The need for sustainable access to data
The need for sustainable access to data
body: Why do we need sustainable access to data?

_items.text: To allow others to validate research outputs
To allow others to build on existing research and data
To allow others to build services on top of the data
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Sustainable access to data is important for a number of reasons. Being able to validate and build upon existing research is only one part of the argument. Digitally-enabled services rely on sustainable access to relevant data, provided in a way that enables integration, analysis and use to reduce risk and improve decisions. Sustainable access supports data ecosystems, because it gives organisations the confidence to invest in using data to develop new products, services and research.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Sustainable access to data is important for a number of reasons. Being able to validate and build upon existing research is only one part of the argument. Digitally-enabled services rely on sustainable access to relevant data, provided in a way that enables integration, analysis and use to reduce risk and improve decisions. Sustainable access supports data ecosystems, because it gives organisations the confidence to invest in using data to develop new products, services and research.

title: When to plan for sustainable access to data
When to plan for sustainable access to data
body: When should sustainable access to data be considered?

_items.text: At the “Refine Proposal” stage of an investment
Any time after the grant proposal has been submitted.
After grantees know what data has been collected.
At the end of the grant period, when all related information is ready to be archived.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Planning for sustainable access to data should be built in from the very beginning of the grant proposal. People frequently make assumptions about what will happen when a project using data ends, without consulting people and organisations impacted by these assumptions. Too often it is tagged on as a box ticking exercise where a data management plan is produced and very little action taken as a result. Ensuring sustainable access to data will also incur a cost and this should be budgeted for at the start of the project.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Planning for sustainable access to data should be built in from the very beginning of the grant proposal. People frequently make assumptions about what will happen when a project using data ends, without consulting people and organisations impacted by these assumptions. Too often it is tagged on as a box ticking exercise where a data management plan is produced and very little action taken as a result. Ensuring sustainable access to data will also incur a cost and this should be budgeted for at the start of the project.

title: The aspects that help ensure sustainable access to data
The aspects that help ensure sustainable access to data
body: There are three key factors that help ensure sustainable access to data:

_items.title: Policies and processes
_items.body:
Policies, including regulations and mandates directly affect sustainable access to data. The foundation has its own Open Access Policy which requires data underlying the published research results be immediately accessible and open. Many publishers also have similar policies to ensure that research is reproducible. 

Outside of research, many governments have policies that require the publication and sharing of data that is essential in delivering societal, environmental and/or economic benefits to everyone. Such data often includes public sector data including geographic, environmental, demographic and financial data.

Processes, including Data Management Plans ensure that all relevant aspects of data management and requirements for longer term access to data are considered, and people, processes and resources are in place.

_items.title: People
_items.body: Sustainable access to data depends on data stewardship. Assigning roles to people ensures it is clear who decides about and invests in datasets so they are accessible and usable in the long term.  Such roles must be suitably resourced with appropriate time committed to managing and sustaining data.

_items.title: Technology
_items.body: People, policies and processes need to be supported by appropriate standards and  technology to curate and control access to the data. There are many ways data can be stored to support future access and use. Open access platforms help to make open data sustainable. Non-open data can also be sustainable when it is stored in ways that sustain access over time to appropriate users. The Gates Open Research platform provides guidance on preparing data for publication and a non-exhaustive list of repositories approved by the Foundation.

title: Checking requirements
body: There are many ways to store and manage data to ensure sustainable access over time. The choice of solution will be affected by many aspects. The questions outlined in this section can help explore the key requirements that will affect the choices made.

title: What are the legal and contractual obligations?
body:
Do we need to retain the data legally?
Governments may require certain commitments or action - for example the Ethiopian Government requires that soil and agronomy data is maintained in a database system by the Ministry of Agriculture in order to ensure that data will be reliably accessible to the research community in the future. 

Do policies and mandates require the publication of data? Under what conditions? 
The BMGF open access policy requires that data underlying the published research results be immediately accessible and open. 

How long does the data need to be available for?
Does it need to be removed after a certain period of time (for example for privacy reasons)?

title: What are the legal and contractual obligations?
Who are the data users and what are their goals?
body:
Partners, funders, customers or users of a service may specify clear needs to access or use data over a longer period of time, or may have their own strategic goals related to providing access to data that have an impact on how sustainable data collected during a grant needs to be.

The data ecosystem mapping tool helps to map out both existing and potential reusers of data and will help define requirements for sustainability.

title: Who are the data users and what are their goals?
What are the legal and contractual obligations?
body:
Is the data suitable for use in digital enabled services and require ongoing updates and maintenance to ensure relevance? 

The Gates Open Research platform provides guidance on preparing data for publication and a non-exhaustive list of repositories approved by the BMGF. It also describes the desirable properties of a repository, which should:

  • Enable access to the dataset
  • Ensure dataset persistence
  • Ensure dataset stability
  • Enable searching and retrieval of datasets

title: What is the scope of the data reuse?
Is the chosen solution suitable for the capability of both current and potential users?
body:
Consider such things as:

  • Using existing standards rather than creating new ones
  • Use already existing and widely used identifiers for things
  • Document your data, describe its attributes, features and limitations
  • Showcasing existing ways to use the data
  • Being an active member of the community, allowing others to reach out to you for help or to make suggestions.

There are many self assessment tools that allow data publishers to show they are following best practices in making data findable, accessible, interoperable and reusable, enabling data reusers to use data with confidence.

title: How will sustainable access be funded?
body: Alternatively data may be deposited or handed off to a third party. At this point it is important to carefully consider the commitment to sustainable access to data of the third party, including aspects such as funding as well as conflicting or commercial interests that may affect access to data. For example an agreement between the research repository FigShare and the LOCKSS (Lots Of Copies Keeps Stuff Safe) alliance means that if a “trigger event” is caused on FigShare (e.g. they cease to exist or a commercial interest changes access permissions) then the controlled copy in the LOCKSS archive can be released.

title: How will sustainable access be funded?
Types of data repositories
body: There are several different types of data repository, each fulfil a different need and set of requirements.

_items.title: Research data repositories
_items.body: Research data repositories come in two main flavours, discipline-specific and interdisciplinary, and broadly allow anyone to contribute data. Some of the more established interdisciplinary repositories include Dataverse, FigShare and Zenodo. Many of these are backed by large communities of funders as well as academic journals who partner with them in order to ensure sustainable access to research data. Disciplinary research repositories are also popular and include specific repositories such as Protein Data Bank and ChemSpider.

_items.title: Government data platforms
_items.body: Government data platforms provide a platform through which any government or country specific data can be accessed. Governments often have clauses which require anyone working with specific types of data, be it as a government department or third party organisation, to make data available via the official government platform. Examples include data.gov.uk, data.gov.in and opendata.go.tz.

_items.title: Curated data repositories
_items.body: Curated data repositories, such as the FAO Data bank,  World Bank open data portal and land portal, provide sustainable access to carefully managed and curated sets of reference data. Unlike the general research repositories, curated data repositories are able to offer data services (such as direct access to the data via an API rather than just file downloads). Each of these providers are sustainable through country memberships and donor contributions. A curated data repository provides most flexibility for providing specific data services however establishing and sustaining a curated data repository is challenging and many are not able to be sustained long term.

_items.title: Code and data platforms
_items.body: A number of providers provide a hybrid platform somewhere between the research data repository and the curated data repository. Such code and data platforms offer management features such as version control, ingest pipelines and validation services. One of the most popular platforms for both code and data is GitHub.

title: Choosing a data repository
body: Match the following datasets to the most appropriate data repository that provides sustainable access?

_items.text: A static research dataset related to a research publication:
A survey of agricultural land use in Ethiopia
An evolving set of analysis and continually updating data

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

One platform is not going to match the needs of all data users and types of data. It is important to consider carefully aspects such as the type of data, how often it is updated as well as who potential users of the data are and what they require. 

A static dataset related to a research publication is best off in a research data repository (such as FigShare). 

Due to a legal requirement in Ethiopia, a copy of the agricultural data must be deposited in the government platform (this is not to say it cannot also be deposited somewhere else also). 

For continually evolving data, a platform more suited to handling regular updates, such as GitHub, could be used. 

If there is concern about the sustainability of a single platform, then consider using a number of different platforms. A number of different platforms may also better suit the needs of different users and sets of requirements in your data ecosystem.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

One platform is not going to match the needs of all data users and types of data. It is important to consider carefully aspects such as the type of data, how often it is updated as well as who potential users of the data are and what they require. 

A static dataset related to a research publication is best off in a research data repository (such as FigShare). 

Due to a legal requirement in Ethiopia, a copy of the agricultural data must be deposited in the government platform (this is not to say it cannot also be deposited somewhere else also). 

For continually evolving data, a platform more suited to handling regular updates, such as GitHub, could be used. 

If there is concern about the sustainability of a single platform, then consider using a number of different platforms. A number of different platforms may also better suit the needs of different users and sets of requirements in your data ecosystem.

title: Using multiple data repositories and platforms
Using multiple data repositories and platforms
body: What is the advantage of depositing data in multiple data repositories and platforms?

_items.text: Each platform can suit different user needs
Increases the chances of long term sustainable access
Increases the visibility of the data
All of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Unlike a physical asset, data can be replicated and transformed into multiple versions simultaneously. So when considering how to ensure sustainable access to data, rather than consider a single solution, choosing a number of solutions has multiple benefits. This also has benefits when one of the solutions might be required legally but not be appropriate for everyone. Planning early can also help ensure that preparing and depositing data in multiple places is easier from day one.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Unlike a physical asset, data can be replicated and transformed into multiple versions simultaneously. So when considering how to ensure sustainable access to data, rather than consider a single solution, choosing a number of solutions has multiple benefits. This also has benefits when one of the solutions might be required legally but not be appropriate for everyone. Planning early can also help ensure that preparing and depositing data in multiple places is easier from day one.

title: Planning for sustainable access to data starts with a data management plan
Planning for sustainable access to data starts with a data management plan
body: Data should be actively managed to;

_items.text: ensure that data is not lost or corrupted
ensure the security of sensitive data
make data FAIR – Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable
ensure that data is made open, for anyone to access, use and share, where possible
all of the above

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

A data management plan outlines how data are to be handled both during a project, and after the project is completed. The goal of a data management plan is to consider the many aspects of data management before the project begins to ensure data is safeguarded and shared as widely as possible. . Creating a data management plan should, ideally, be a collaborative, iterative, process involving all stakeholders in a project, including financial donors.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

title: What should a data management plan outline?
What should a data management plan outline?
body: Which of the following should be included in a data management plan?

_items.text: A clear list and description of data in scope
A list of roles and responsibilities
A clear and realistic budget
Descriptions of the data analysis being performed
An outline of a potential future project that reuses the data

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

A good data management plan will include elements related to sustainability of data such as;

  • A data inventory that lists the data and identifies any third party rights in the data
  • A list of platforms and agreements that support the sustainability of the data (e.g. in government data platforms)
  • A set of roles and responsibilities related to the continued management of data
  • A clear and realistic budget
  • Any training or capacity development needs that will support sustainable access to the data

There is no one-size-fits-all approach to managing data and the appropriate course of action will need to take into account the nature of the data and its intended use. The related guide on Developing a data management plan: a checklist can help ensure that an effective data management plan is put in place.

title: Sustainable access and FAIR data
body: Match the long descriptions to the relevant aspect of the FAIR acronym.

_items.text: The data can be easily combined and integrated with other data though the use of standard language, structure and data formats.
Both humans and machines can easily retrieve, view and process the data without the need for complex retraining.
The data is clearly licensed so both humans and machines understand their rights and permissions for use.
Data is listed and referenced from many places using links and identifiers that help people navigate to the data.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Findable data is listed and referenced from many places using links and identifiers that help people navigate to the data.

Accessible data is that which both humans and machines can easily retrieve, view and process the data without the need for complex retraining. 

Interoperable data can be easily combined and integrated with other data though the use of standard language, structure and data formats.

Reusable data is clearly licensed so both humans and machines understand their rights and permissions for use.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Findable data is listed and referenced from many places using links and identifiers that help people navigate to the data.

Accessible data is that which both humans and machines can easily retrieve, view and process the data without the need for complex retraining. 

Interoperable data can be easily combined and integrated with other data though the use of standard language, structure and data formats.

Reusable data is clearly licensed so both humans and machines understand their rights and permissions for use.

title: Summary
body:
Planning for sustainable access to data should be built in from the very beginning of the grant proposal.

Sustainable access to data is critical to ensure that data remains FAIR and safeguarded over the long term. It is one thing to make data Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable (FAIR).

There are many ways to store and manage data to ensure sustainable access over time. The choice of solution will be affected by many aspects.

The related guide on Developing a data management plan: a checklist can help ensure that an effective data management plan is put in place.

_items.title: How to create a data inventory: a checklist
_items.body:
This short guide provides

  • a summary of the benefits of creating a data inventory
  • an outline of the steps to create a data inventory
  • some recommendations about what metadata to include in an inventory

Download the guide

_items.title: Gates Open Research - Data guidelines
_items.body:
Gates Open Research requires that the source data underlying the results are made available as soon as an article is published. The Gates open research data guidelines provide information about what data is in scope, how it can be stored, and how data should be presented.

Download the guide

_items.title: Data ecosystem mapping tool
_items.body:
A data ecosystem map illustrates the different actors in a data ecosystem, and how value is exchanged. It helps illustrate the needs for sustainable access to data and gives a visual indication of who the key stakeholders are and what their requirements might be. 

This sits alongside the understanding personas in agricultural data ecosystems guide. which looks at some practical examples of ecosystems in agriculture and outlines the different types of personas based upon interviews with stakeholders.

Download the ecosystem mapping tool
